Recent research has confirmed that different tissues in the body replace cells at different rates, and some tissues never replace cells. So the statement that we replace every cell in the body every seven years or every ten years is wrong. Using a revolutionary new technique (described below), researchers have shown that:
- Neurons in the cerebral cortex are never replaced. There are no neurons added to your cerebral cortex after birth. Any cerebral cortex neurons that die are not replaced.
- Fat cells are replaced at the rate of about 10% per year in adults. So you could say that on average, human beings replace all their fat cells about every ten years.
- Cardiomyocyte heart cells are replaced at a reducing rate as we age. At age 25, about 1% of cells are replaced every year. Replacement slows gradually to about 0.5% at age 70. Even in people who have lived a very long life, less than half of the cardiomyocyte cells have been replaced. Those that aren’t replaced have been there since birth.

+Ben Allen
'Here is a question, if we can so easily regrow all our cells in out body, why can't we regrow lost limbs?'

Well, the reason we can't replace limbs by regrowing them once they are lost is to do with cell regeneration and stem cells, are contraception there are a lot of stem cells which will slowly turn into specialized cells and repeat that process all through its life, the it will COPY it self (chromosomes), to the new cell when its renewed.

This means when the cell is lost completely, there is no more blueprint of that specialized chromosome to replenish it self, to regrow.

But this is also why if we get a specialized cell of an organ or some kind, and implant it into a stem cell we can grown artificial organic organs, but of course we have no idea what the long term effect is so for now we stay to the simple things.

"Every atom in your body is different now" - This isn't true.  Your source-link claims every cell is replaced (which is very different from every atom being replaced), but even that's not true.  For example, the enamel in your teeth *never* regrows.

Human beings breathe automatically, as in without thinking about it. However, this is only true when they actually aren't thinking about it. For the majority of people, being reminded that they are breathing causes them to begin to control their breath on a conscious level, as in with deliberate effort to continue breathing. Thus, being told they are breathing manually causes people to breathe manually, continue to do so until they forget and go back to auto, which can't be done by choice.

Skin cells may die, but the ink particles don't. What happens in a tattoo is that the ink is forced by the needle deep down into the skin; the ink particles near the surface get pushed out as the skin cells are replaced, but the particles deeper down are "eaten" by phagocytic cells, like macrophages. they can't break down the ink particles so they get stuck there; when the macrophage later dies, it gets eaten by another macrophage which has the same problem. So the ink just stays there (:

The Observable Universe is expanding at the speed of light, ~300,000 km/s, which we cannot exceed. In any case, the universe has a ~13.8 billion lightyear head start.

It's a bit like asking 'What's north of the North Pole?'. Well, you can't get more north than the North Pole, so the question is moot.

Because light enters our eyes, being inverted by the convex lens below our iris. The inverted light travels through the vitreous humor (a bunch of goo), hits our retina, then is transmitted by the optic nerve, through the brain, to the occipital lobe of the brain, where the light is re-reversed so that it is regular, causing us to see the correct image (we therefore technically see with our brains, not our eyes. Our eyes are just receptors).

Btw, in case you didn't know Cleopatra was from a Greek family. She might have even been fully Greek (although she WAS born in Egypt) but it's hard to tell because we don't know her mother's background. She loved the Egyptian culture, though, and wanted to become more Egyptian herself.
And, á propos, did you know that at the time of Cleopatra and Julius Caesar, Greek was the de facto official language of the Roman Empire? Latin became the common language much later and only in the west.

I absolutely love the Cleopatra fact because it gives you a lot of perspective to history. It's so easy to forget that the ancient Egyptian culture lasted for longer than Christianity or even Judaism have been around. And I was surprised too, to find that the period of the pyramid building was very early in Egyptian history. And still it's undeniably a continuous culture throughout that time, as much as it changed on the way and had different rulers (who all became Egyptianized).

Atoms have a nucleus, but the rest of it is composed of the electron cloud. In the electron cloud, electrons move at the speed of light around the nucleus. They are more likely to be found closer to the nucleus, but there are a few that go farther away, making it a bit bigger. With all of that scattered movement and dispersed placement of the electrons, it creates a lot of empty space in the atom.

If there is no person or animal around (nothing with an ear), then no, because the falling of the tree just cause the air molecules to move (compression and rarefraction). In order for it to make a sound those air molecules work have to work on your sensory organ (the ear). The movement cause vibrations in the ear (through many small parts) cause neurones to fire, sending the signal to the brain, which then interprets it as a sound. So without an ear, it is just moving air molecules.

to see why there's no such thing as "empty" space.

In fact, there's no such thing as "empty" space because, there's always quantum fluctuations that produce virtual particles, etc. Actually, the mass of the proton (which consists of three quarks [two up and one down]) comes from the "fields" that come in and out of existence between the quarks within the protons, not from the quarks themselves. The protons & neutrons give mass to the nucleus, which gives mass to you. Thus, the atom, and thus the universe, is NOT 99% empty space. That's silly.

@0:56

I just don't see how an atom can be "99% empty space" because, the probability of finding an electron around a nucleus is practically anywhere. For example, an atom of carbon has two electrons in the 1s atomic orbital, which has no nodes, two electrons in the 2s AO (which has one node), and 2 electrons in two of the three 2p AOs (each of which have one node). Since the electron can be anywhere in their orbitals (except at the nodes), the atom seems full, not empty, to me.

The fact about your body replacing all its cells in ten years is a common misconception. Fat cells are replaced at about 10% per year, but heart muscle cells turn over at just 1% per year at age 25, declining to 0.5% by the age of 70. Even if you live to be 100 you will still have over half the heart muscle cells you were born with. The neurons of the cerebral cortex and the cells in the lens of your eyes are never normally replaced. 
That brings me to the question, how many facts are 100% true?

Both of these require Carbon in relatiely large amounts, and while carbon dioxide makes up onlyabout 0,00001% of earths atmosphere, its both quite a lot in context, and an easy source of molecular carbon.
